csoundo
Class Csoundo

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Thread
      csoundo.Csoundo
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
public class Csoundo
extends java.lang.Thread

+Example
/*
 * Demonstrates writing data to a csound channel (chn) bus then reading
 * back the data. Move the mouse pointer around the screen.
 *
 * Example by Jacob Joaquin
 */

import csoundo.*;

Csoundo cs;

void setup() {
    size(740, 480);
    frameRate(30);
    smooth();

    cs = new Csoundo(this, "chnInOut.csd");
    cs.run();
}

void draw() {
    background(0);
    
    // Send mouse position to Csound chn busses
    cs.setChn("mouse_x", mouseX / (float) width);
    cs.setChn("mouse_y", (1 - (mouseY / (float) height)));
    
    // Read chn busses
    float mx = cs.getChn("mouse_x");
    float my = cs.getChn("mouse_y");
    
    ellipseMode(RADIUS);
    fill(255, mx * 255, 0, my * 255);
    ellipse(width / 2.0, height / 2.0, 200, 200);
}

Constructor Detail

Csoundo

public Csoundo(processing.core.PApplet theParent,
               java.lang.String _csd)
The Csoundo constructor, usually called in the setup() method in your sketch. Only supports 1 csd file for now, regardless of the number of instances of Csoundo you are running. Your Csound csd file must reside in the /data folder of your sketch. A temporary CSD file called __CSOUNDO__.csd is created in your /data folder.

Parameters:
theParent - The PApplet. Usually pass 'this'
f - The Csound file to run. Requires full absolute path.

setOptions

public void setOptions(java.lang.String s)
Overwrites the Csound options. Default options are '-g -odac' where -g sets graphics to display as ascii characters in the console output and -odac means to send audio to the default digital-audio-converter.

Parameters:
Command-line - string
